comments.commentBody:
I absolutely remember the one guest who did not give us a wedding gift. I also remember her telling me that she bought a designer dress to wear to the wedding, so clearly she didn't mind spending money on her attire.

When the beautiful Tiffany candlesticks had no card attached, I sought to find the gift giver so that we could thank them. There were three possible candidates; this particular friend said, "Nope. Not from me."

Giving a gift is customary for birthdays, holidays, bridal/baby showers and yes, weddings. Are people "required" to give gifts at these celebrations? Of course not. Nobody is "required" to do anything. But to go to a friend's wedding, bring a date and act like it is just an elegant night out without giving so much as a congratulatory card really takes gall.

I celebrate life events with friends and family by not only attending the event, but also in giving a gift. I don't just show up empty handed with a smile.

As for this friend, I definitely re-evaluated our friendship.

I am sorry but if you have feelings of resentment towards people who don't give you a gift for your wedding, you have issues. We were grateful that our friends came to our wedding to celebrate this special day with us. It was the friends and the memories we had of the day that mattered not the materialistic tally.

No.  You give a party (which is what the eating part of a wedding IS) to entertain your guests, not because you want something from them.  It should NEVER be about the gifts and the idea of confronting a guest is beyond crass.  Assume no one will give gifts.  Receptions are for celebrating, not for calculating.
Add some hot sauce (sambal) to your peanut butter sandwich, some slices of cucumber, a few lettuce leaves, a few drops of soy sauce and you have an Indonesian gado-gado salad on a bun.
Not sure what your beef with shallots are, I can think of many more smelly things than them. And besides, that's what a desk toothbrush is for.

Not to mention how it will stink up your desk drawer or the fridge, and then when you discard the leftovers, it will stink up the trash.

Yet more reasons that people eat out.
If you are eating a salty, sugary "frozen dinner" (yeah, even the diet variations), you are likely not eating anything better for you than a simple salad or sandwich from a deli.

Like Bittman always misses, the devil is in the details.

Yes, some workplaces have nice lunchrooms, with full-size refrigerators and microwaves, even stoves. They have a sink to wash up stuff. They also may have nice, civilized fellow employees who don't steal your lunch, and don't leave "mystery leftovers' stinking up the fridge for weeks.

But that's not reality for most people. For starters -- not everyone by far works in an "office". If you work in a retail store, or are on the road, or in a factory, or outdoors, this will not likely work well.

Here is my own office situation: MY office space (shared with 2 other people) IS the former "lunchroom". Hence, there is no lunchroom. The fridge broke, so we have no fridge. There is a microwave, and it's filthy and disgusting, crusted with old food. The only sink is down the hall in the ladies bathroom, which requires the key to open the door. There are no tables, so bringing your means eating at your work station -- no break, no way to get away even for 20 minutes.

So -- you must keep whatever you bring in your desk. Meaning it gets warm, which is disgusting for most foods. Whatever looked fresh last night or this morning (assuming you remember the night before to pack a lunch, or at 6AM) is pretty sad and pathetic by 1PM. If it was frozen, it has melted. (Needless to say, this is also a food safety hazard.)

Cook it up, and it smells up the whole office. This is why people go out to lunch. DUH!

I have always been against assasination, but I am beginning to think that it would be more humane for all on both sides for some nation to send in an assassin against Assad. I truly believe that only God can decide who lives and who dies, but then again, wouldn't it be more economical of human life to simply assassinate Assad?
Of course, that may not even be possible.
I am horrified that I would even consider such an action, but on the other hand the thought of thousands injured and dying from chemical weapons causes me to doubt my own principles.

SteveRR -- The rigor you describe is the model in Finland. And they also pay their teachers like doctors and lawyers. The results speak for themselves -- I would love a move to more rigor and more pay.
Exactly the analogy I was going to make. Thank you.

SteveRR

I am not sure how things work in CA, but I had to pass a rigorous exam to earn and maintain my license on at least 2 occasions. Significant numbers of newly minted college graduates failed the same tests each time so therefore the exam must have been at least somewhat rigorous.

Removing a public school teacher for cause is not difficult if the administration follows through on their responsibilities. MD's have to kill people before their fellow MD's on a review board decide to revoke a license to practice medicine.

Let's use a parallel in medicine. Let's say MD's practiced for 2 or 3 years and "moved on." So, would you want your MD in be in this group? What about attorneys? Would you want your attorney to only be with you for a few years and drop you when he/she is around 30 years old? And so on...

So much about education is political rhetoric, with a spin to meet every occasion. This is very disturbing. Our country will suffer for it. The elites will go to elite schools, "play around" for a while, and "move on" and everyone else will be stuck.

I love you Mark (hero-worship is more like it) but you work in New York City and your perspective is therefore terribly skewed. I work in a hospital 11 miles outside of San Francisco. There are no on-site lunch options other than the hospital cafeteria and most of us get a limited break for lunch making a drive impractical. Everyone brings their lunch and there's not a bit of shame in it. I wake up at 5 every day and pack up my breakfast and lunch: some yogurt and fruit; a salad with some tuna or cheese or an avocado or whatever is in the fridge. I figure in the 5 years that I have been doing this, I have probably saved $10,000 dollars and I have lost 10 pounds. Couldn't imagine doing it any other way.

Then there is the other side of the coin: the couple who never sends a thank-you note. You can all me petty, but I remember every couple (thankfully few) who I sent a gift from their regisitry in a timely fashion (mostly one week prior to the wedding so I won't forget) and never received a note. Then there is the couple who married overseas and we could not attend: we handed the bride, a girl we had known all her life, $200 cash ( not an insignificant sum for us) and NEVER received a thank you.  Maybe the worst was the couple whose wedding was a four-hour drive and an overnight stay away who sent PREPRINTED notes: yes, they had many guests, but if they had time to open all the gifts and deposit all the checks they had time to write short notes. Do I still send gifts? If I attend the wedding, always. If I do not attend I am inclined not to.
Jeeze, speak for yourself.
Similarly, the giver of a wedding gift that is not acknowledged with a thank you note never forgets that slight.

Didn't send a gift for a wedding they didn't attend? Pretty sure that's ok with both Miss Manners & Mrs. Post, so get over it, Snapple lady.
Not writing a thank you note? Far worse, and inexcusable.

Who has an hour or more to go out to eat, which takes maybe 10 minutes? Another vegan here. When I'm in my office, I often heat up a flax lavashe or whole grain wrap with black beans, quinoa, vegetables, kale, guacamole, hummus, and/or picante, or make a sandwich, or have some fruit, etc. it's delicious, healthy, and fast. Thanks as always, Mark.

Instead of having a pot of beans, why not make a variation on chili con carne? Beef, lamb, vegetarian - with a bit of rice reheated this can make my day.

Worst luncheon experiences: the dreadfully overcooked green beans at some prestigious advanced studies institute in Paris. No wonder French delis serve pureed vegetables. Or the time I had fried chicken from the university cafeteria. My anthropology colleague picked up a bone and concluded: calcium deficiency, lack of exercise, raised for rapid growth. Two arguments for bringing your own lunch.

We are also commemorating a moment when black Americans, joined by other Americans of good will, spoke truth to power and stood up for the best in American democracy.  Let's honor the memory of Dr. King and those courageous Americans who stood with him that day, and let's recommit to healing our divisions.

Personally- I am sick of sending expensive gifts (we are talking several hundred dollars a gift) to children of friends and NEVER GETTING A THANK YOU NOTE!!

I always get them items from their registry even if it is not my taste and I send them as soon as the invite arrives. So why don't they send a note in appreciation?

My girls will be getting married in a few short years and I will murder them if they are not on top of their thank yous. Frankly, I raised them better than that so I am not really worried.

Did you give a nice card with a personal note congratulating them and wishing them happiness? Maybe noting they were so important you made the sacrifice of the cost to see them rather than miss their day? That's the way to do the no gift thing-give a nice card. At least then it's clear no need to search for your gift in the piles of stuff they received.
You actually sent them an invoice in the guise of a thank you note?
According to this article the pettiness of privilege cannot be overestimated.

Your mother was precisely correct. Let's face it -- no one really likes attending those overblown, dull parties!

(And yes, I am married. Got married at City Hall and took the 11 guests, all of whom were family or very close friends, out for dim sum and cupcakes afterward.)

I wish I could recommend your advice to give thanks over and over.
Graditude makes for a happier life. And if we have food on the table and a roof over our head then we have much for which to be grateful.
You're a high-powered attorney for two decades and it didn't occur to you to be circumspect when taking on the record to the New York Times?
Purrrr-fect!  IAnn, if I ever run into you we'll laugh til it hurts!
